content: The Act titled "Restoring Fiscal Discipline Act of 2007" includes a provision for a pay-as-you-go point of order in the Senate. The "Restoring Fiscal Discipline Act of 2007" includes a provision for a pay-as-you-go point of order in the Senate, which restricts consideration of legislation that would increase the on-budget deficit for specific time periods. Direct-spending legislation refers to bills, resolutions, amendments, motions, or conference reports that impact direct spending as defined by the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985. This definition excludes concurrent resolutions on the budget and provisions affecting the deposit insurance guarantee commitment. This section outlines that all direct spending and revenue legislation enacted since the beginning of the calendar year not included in the baseline, except for deficit reduction enacted through reconciliation instructions, shall not be available. The waiver or suspension of this section in the Senate requires a three-fifths majority vote. Appeals related to this section in the Senate are limited to 1 hour and require a three-fifths majority vote to sustain an appeal of the ruling. The Budget Enforcement Act of 1990 established baseline estimates for budget authority, outlays, and revenues. The Committee on the Budget of the Senate determines these levels for each fiscal year. This section will expire on September 30, 2012. SEC. 3. RECONCILIATION FOR DEFICIT REDUCTION OR INCREASING THE SURPLUS in the Senate. In the Senate, under expedited reconciliation procedures, any bill, resolution, amendment, or conference report that increases the deficit or reduces the surplus in specified fiscal years is not allowed. Additionally, resolutions related to the budget cannot be considered if they conflict with deficit reduction or surplus increase goals. Under expedited reconciliation procedures in the Senate, any resolution containing a reconciliation directive that would increase the deficit or reduce the surplus in specified fiscal years is not allowed. A supermajority vote is required to waive or appeal this rule in the Senate.
